8.14.text:
We now face an existential crisis that may
bring human civilisation to an end. This needs

15.04.text: a whole of society effort to try and resolve it.

19.26.text:
Our current system is a planet-killing Ponzi
scheme. It’s a giant casino of absolutely

24.90.text: The consumer way very easily debauches.

27.87.text:
I think we are losing a sense of community
in many ways.

33.14.text:
We need to learn about these fundamentals of
a deeper connection to one another

39.86.text:
Maybe there’s another option, maybe there’s
another way - way to live which isn’t the

45.07.text:
way that I have grown up with or become accustomed
to or just fallen into.

66.16.text:
The story of industrial civilisation tells
us that limitless economic growth, advanced

72.04.text:
technology, and material affluence are the
pathways to prosperity. But as we reflect

78.65.text:
on the world today, it is clear that this
is failing both people and planet. We know

86.10.text: this in our heads and feel it in our hearts.

91.73.text:
And yet, it seems we have not found a new
story by which to live. We are the generation

97.66.text:
in between stories, desperately clinging to
yesterday’s, but uncertain of tomorrow’s.

104.96.text:
But then again, perhaps the new story is already
with us.

109.48.text: Perhaps we just need to live it into existence.

184.44.text:
I came because I was looking for a way to
simplify my life. I knew that the way that

191.15.text:
I was living my life wasn’t right and the
things that seemed – that it seemed necessary

196.70.text:
to strive for weren’t the things that I
really wanted to strive for. And I’ve always

199.93.text:
felt that. [Beautiful windows.] So I guess
for the last five or six years I’ve sort

205.76.text:
of been paring back. I just, yeah, I felt
I didn’t want to have debt, I didn’t want

213.32.text:
to… didn’t want to feel obligated to work
a 40-hour week and not have time to do the

218.80.text: things that really mattered to me.

220.92.text:
So, for the past year or so I’ve been experimenting
with, I guess, living simply, living sustainably,

228.53.text:
and trying to challenge myself, I guess, to
live in a way that is less ah harmful towards

233.43.text:
the planet and, ah, less energy intensive.
I guess I feel like this experiment is an

237.70.text:
opportunity to push myself a little bit further
and challenge not only myself but the modern

242.32.text:
environmental movement to, yeah, come to understand
what it is to live sustainably.

248.08.text:
I’m really looking forward to this year,
being part of a team working together to explore,

254.33.text:
ah, what it really means to live simply and
sustainably, to work towards living within

261.30.text:
the resources of one planet. How we can just
improve constantly. And I’m really excited

268.09.text:
about sharing that beyond the group here and
beyond this place as much as we can to inspire

274.97.text:
The idea of this project really interested
me because I’d been trying to apply these

278.50.text:
principles in my own life in quite an individual
way, hadn’t had much support from the wider

284.20.text:
group of people I was with, so the idea of
coming here to be in a supportive learning

287.84.text:
environment and to be meeting lots of new
people who are asking similar questions, challenging

293.00.text:
things in a similar way, that’s what excited
me, that idea of working as part of a larger

298.64.text:
Ah, I guess my interest in this project was
to join with like-minded people, learn some

306.79.text:
skills, give my daughter the opportunity of
living, living on a rural property. Being

314.38.text:
part of a documentary to…to educate and
inspire others to one planet living, sustainable

321.94.text:
Um, so I was interested in this project because
it provided me with the ability to put the

326.37.text:
theories of natural building and natural food
production into practice on a bigger scale

331.39.text:
than I’m able to do in cities and without
actually buying any land, because land’s

338.26.text:
I’ve been studying permaculture for a long
time, but I’m excited to put it into practice.

342.93.text:
I want to have experiences and I wanna be
able to use my hands, and have knowledge from

351.85.text:
In terms of the existing infrastructure, in
addition to the house there, there’s a small

361.34.text:
earth ship, a cob round house, some basic
composting facilities, and a moderately sized

370.89.text:
farm shed, if you like. My mother loved this
place. So much so that my sister and I spread

377.52.text:
her ashes here, once she passed away. She
is very much the seed for us, in being able

386.27.text:
to explore sustainable pathways for the property.
It was not long after this that I was introduced

394.59.text:
to Samuel Alexander’s book Entropia, and
realised that we were truly on the same page,

400.51.text:
envisaging a simpler way. I shared all this
with the Gunai Kernai Land and Waters Aboriginal

409.80.text:
Corporation’s cultural heritage manager
about our small Braiakolung patch, and Wurruk’an

417.92.text:
was born. With permission to use “Wurruk”,
a local indigenous word for earth and story,

429.39.text:
fused with “k’an”, a Mayan term for
seed.

441.28.text:
We are beginning the build of a tiny house.
It’s about 2.7 by 3.6, and about 3 metres

449.35.text:
high, so it’s got a footprint of about 10
square metres. We’re trying to use as much

455.92.text:
reclaimed timber and reclaimed iron as possible.
For the last two or three months I’ve been

461.40.text:
jumping into skips on the side of the road
or jumping into people’s back yards when

464.59.text:
they tell me that they’re renovating, or
going to the tip shops or salvage yards or

468.62.text:
finding windows on the side of the road. We’ve
got about 15 people here for the build over

474.38.text:
the next week and at the end of that build
I’m hoping that we’ve more or less got

480.87.text:
ourselves a beautiful, unconventional, tiny
house.

564.80.text:
This is the tiny house that was built by a
group of people in, when was it, it was January,

572.34.text:
as well, so it took about a week, and then
I had to install some of the ceiling and a

580.13.text:
few other bits and pieces myself, but it got
finished in a week. So this is the outside

585.41.text:
of the tiny house. It’s made out of pretty
much nearly all recycled materials, building

590.72.text:
materials, it’s probably about, I would
say about 95% all recycled building materials.

596.84.text:
These weather boards are actually skirting
boards that we sanded down and varnished.

603.23.text:
So I guess that the main feature of the tiny
house is the geodesic window, which our carpenter

611.51.text:
Nick made. It’s beautiful. He actually made
the frame and I cut all the glass and did

619.53.text:
the patterns. First time cutting glass and,
what do you know it worked! And then I made

625.18.text:
a candle-holder for it and everything. This
makes it a really warm and beautiful space

629.79.text:
to be in and I look forward to many winter
nights with candles. Then we’ve got, like

636.08.text:
most tiny houses we’ve got a loft for either
storage or a bed. That’s my bed up there.

642.20.text:
It’s got a really cute little window. You
can fit quite a lot of things into a tiny

646.95.text:
house and to be honest it’s quite comfortable.
I’ve got my couch, my bed, I’ve got a

652.51.text:
work station as well. This is my little desk,
where I end up doing designs from, which is

660.91.text:
a really beautiful place to work. I often
work with the door open, I’ve got a view

664.98.text:
down into the valley there. I often work with
a kerosene lamp, candles, sometimes a head

672.35.text:
torch if it’s getting a little bit too dark.
There’s no power in the house and that’s

678.85.text:
what I like about it. I like to kind of go
back to nature and it really gives you a feeling

685.50.text:
of the fluctuations of the seasons and the
cycles of nature as well. I prefer to live

691.42.text:
in a tiny space. I like to nest, and I don’t
think that you miss out on much … much more

699.32.text:
than living in a conventional house, in a
quite a larger house, and that’s because

704.65.text:
it makes you minimise, it makes you realise
how much you don’t need, as well. It makes

709.18.text:
you realise how functional a small space can
be. In our modern society we have the, usually

716.16.text:
the feeling that bigger is better, and I don’t
necessarily think that that’s the case.

721.80.text:
I think that smaller is more cosy and more
nourishing.

741.92.text:
I grew up in quite a conventional way, in
a little family in sort of suburban England,

748.04.text:
but my family had a really strong connection
to the natural world. We’d often go for

753.05.text:
walks in the forest and along moors and I
had a deep love of nature from a young age.

758.73.text:
And when I was a teenager I, through videos
on the internet and through publications,

763.95.text:
discovered the extent of the ecological and
social crises happening in the world today

767.95.text:
– the deforestation, the pollution in the
oceans, the toxic dumps, the factory farming.

774.26.text:
That really hit me very hard and I became
really concerned about how we were living.

779.27.text:
I had a deep sense that we shouldn’t be
going down that track but at the time I had

783.79.text: no idea that there was an alternative.

789.75.text:
You can’t produce an answer unless you name
the problem accurately. Unless we really understand

796.99.text:
the circumstances we’re in, we’re not
gonna get the solutions to find the path to

800.82.text:
it and I’ve seen what I call, after Barbara
Ehrenreich, a lot of bright siding. Aah…

806.51.text:
It’s all happy-clappy, it’s all good,
we’re all going in the right direction,

810.79.text:
there’s renewable energy, sunflowers, all
of this. I think, in part, some of that is

818.07.text:
a personal psychological response of people
wanting to talk about the good news because

822.50.text:
it allows them to go on. But we have to deal
with this problem as it really is, and it

829.20.text:
is arresting and it is difficult. And to pretend
otherwise, to pretend it’s going to be light

835.08.text:
and easy, that it’s going to be business
as usual, that everybody can keep on making

838.91.text:
profit and we won’t have to change much,
to think like that, actually means that we

843.97.text:
can’t get to the solution we need. We need
brutal reality in order to solve the problem.

851.58.text:
Techno-optimism in particular is, is really
insidious, it’s about telling us we don’t

856.04.text:
actually have to change anything, we can still
have everything we have now. So we don’t

859.38.text:
have to worry about any of these pesky limits,
we’ll have everything we have now we’ll

864.24.text:
just do it all in a green sort of way. … I
think we have to have a recognition of the

869.04.text:
fact that we are facing limits, and some sense
of the relative timeframe for the different

873.49.text:
limits that we’re facing, because then we
know what we’re trying to prepare for, and

878.14.text:
we have an appropriate kind of sense of urgency
as to the need to do it.

882.50.text:
I hope that by the end of the year I’ll
have a deeper grounding in what it means to

889.04.text:
live simply, and a greater confidence that
this is in fact a way of approaching life

894.01.text:
that is deeply nourishing. I believe it is
and the experiences I’ve had so far tell

899.20.text:
me that it’s something that could be applied
to lots of peoples’ lives for great benefit,

903.54.text:
but I think the explorations of this year
will help give me confidence in communicating

908.18.text:
that message and sharing it with a wide range
of people. I hope that by the end of the year

912.86.text:
these practical explorations will give me
greater clarity of my own realities and vision

917.72.text:
and how I see my life being a beautiful contribution
to these difficult times that we’re in as

923.44.text:
a species. I want my life to be a gesture
towards a more stable and loving world.

932.28.text:
I guess I’m expecting this year to be difficult.
I’m expecting to, yeah, again push simple

942.44.text:
living to its probably more extreme ends and
try and, I mean I know it’s gonna be uncomfortable

947.02.text:
but I wanna try and find what my limits are
and try and pare it back to something that’s

951.28.text:
somewhere in between and more comfortable.
And I guess I’ve been doing that by myself

954.77.text:
for a little while now and I’m hoping to
do that with a bunch of other people that

958.60.text:
are interested in the same kind of thing and
maybe we can work together and as a community

961.50.text:
it might be more rewarding or more enjoyable
or even a bit easier. And yeah I mean if you

967.00.text:
can extend that to community living, I guess
it’ll be easier to extend to much broader

973.29.text:
[Oh ok, no it’s not matching up anymore.]
I spent the last eight years working in an

982.85.text:
office, as a town planner, in a number of
different roles, doing different things and

989.75.text:
in the end of those eight years I was actually
partaking in projects that I was very passionate

996.04.text:
about, but the bulk of my work that was coming
from up above, my bosses, was not something

1002.37.text:
I was proud or really fully passionate about.
So quitting my job and doing a bit of travelling

1013.23.text:
and then applying to be a part of this project
gave me the ability to remove myself from

1021.01.text:
the daily grind, I guess you could say, and
you know I found that once I you know built

1028.77.text:
my salary up over those eight years working
from part time to a full time, senior employee

1033.97.text:
in a local government, I started spending
that money on luxuries, and since I’ve quit

1040.30.text:
my job it’s been nice to just strip all
those things back and try and live more simply

1047.51.text:
with far less. So over the year I’m hoping
that I’ll be able to construct some form

1053.88.text:
of abode on wheels for very little money,
as I don’t have much, using recycled materials

1062.47.text:
I’ve always had sort of minor health issues
and in my mid-30s they’d developed to a

1071.35.text:
point where it was necessary for me to really
do something … to really take responsibility

1076.49.text:
for my health, because I wasn’t finding
the medical profession helpful and I wasn’t

1084.20.text:
finding anything else that was helping me,
and so I started taking responsibility for

1087.98.text:
my health. And as I understood more about
the way my body works, and the importance

1095.21.text:
of the food that I put in it, and that food
is medicine, and the importance of knowing

1100.17.text:
where your food comes from, and connecting
with your food, the more interested I became

1106.97.text:
in soil, and in gardening, which I had never
really… I mean I’d always been a city

1113.20.text:
girl, I never really knew how a strawberry
grew… wouldn’t have recognised half the

1121.27.text:
plants on my plate if I’d seen them in a
garden. So those understandings led me to

1130.53.text:
leave a desk job that I loved but which I
realised wasn’t healthy for me, it wasn’t

1134.62.text:
good for me to sit at a desk for five days
a week all day, every day, it wasn’t good

1140.02.text: for me mentally, or physically, or spiritually.

1142.79.text:
Ok, so this is the cob cabin. It was built
in a workshop about a year and half before

1152.57.text:
the project started. It’s… the walls are
30cm thick cob, which is sand, clay and straw

1159.86.text:
and water, and the floor is also cob. There’s
not a lot to show in the cob cabin because

1166.26.text:
I didn’t come with a lot of things, so I
haven’t got much in here, which I’m really

1170.58.text:
loving. I gave away or sold most of my things
before I came to Australia for this project,

1176.71.text:
which was a really liberating experience.
So obviously in the process of being here

1182.47.text:
I’ve accumulated things, because that’s
what we do. One thing I’ve done is make

1186.58.text:
a bed from pallets. There were some rocks
left over from the build and some planks lying

1194.65.text:
around so I made some shelves from rocks and
planks. I’ve got a little plastic solar

1201.13.text:
powered light, which doesn’t put out much
light, but that’s so … I don’t have

1206.93.text:
any other form of power in the cabin. I’m
not going to have any heating for winter.

1214.80.text:
The walls being 30cm-thick cob, it’s really
well insulated so it’s really cool in summer

1220.73.text:
and so far it’s been really warm on cold
days, but obviously we’re not in the heart

1225.83.text:
of winter yet so I don’t know how it’s
gonna be.

1227.40.text:
We need a certain level of material possessions
to be satisfied but beyond that point, which

1234.28.text:
is surprisingly low, it’s actually less
about what we have and more about the way

1238.67.text:
we live and the way we treat others and the
way we feel ourselves to be in relationship

1243.10.text:
with the wider world, and lots of beautiful
writers spoke very clearly about how people

1250.59.text:
can find more satisfaction in a less consumptive
way, which at the same time makes us happier

1256.19.text:
in the west and it also reduces the load that
we’re putting on other people around the

1260.97.text:
world who don’t have access to the wealth
that we’re taking from them. So voluntary

1267.89.text:
simplicity for me is a very elegant way to
both increase personal satisfaction and sense

1276.47.text:
There’s now a mountain of literature that
is overwhelmingly convincing that not only

1284.58.text:
are there savage limits to growth but we’ve
gone through many of them, in the sense that

1289.50.text:
it is now utterly impossible for all people
to live at anything like the standard of consumption

1297.19.text:
or environmental impact that we have in rich
countries. And yet the mainstream has virtually

1305.21.text:
ignored that case. The economy at the moment,
despite all those brilliant tech-fix things

1311.45.text:
– like the computerisation of everything
– the resource use rates are going up at

1316.97.text:
a fiercer rate. So if technical advance, technical
fix, is going to solve our problems, well

1323.64.text: I want to know is when’s it going to start?

1328.42.text:
It often seems to me that these debates about
our environment, our future and our, you know,

1336.60.text:
environmental future come down to almost a
blind faith in technology. And I should say

1344.91.text:
that by background I’m a technologist, I
come from applied physics background, so,

1351.15.text:
you know, I like what technology does for
us. But, we have to be really careful about

1358.77.text: putting so much faith in this factor.

1361.52.text:
Well, essentially all human political systems
exist to extract wealth from the periphery

1365.99.text:
and concentrate it at the centre. It’s just
that some of them do it a lot more effectively

1370.30.text:
or efficiently than others. Capitalism does
it extremely effectively. So it’s a very

1375.94.text:
effective mechanism for sucking wealth towards
the centre. What you do is you create a Ponzi

1381.46.text:
scheme, essentially, you’re sucking everything
in, but you constantly require a larger and

1386.54.text:
larger periphery to suck it into in order
to keep expanding the capacity of the centre.

1393.18.text:
And if you can’t keep expanding, it will
collapse, like any Ponzi scheme, so you have

1397.64.text: to keep reaching out further and further.

1399.68.text:
I don’t necessarily think it’s certain
that we’re in for collapse or that it’s

1404.92.text:
happening now. I think trying to make such
a call, a certainty call on this is, would

1407.29.text:
be extremely brave. But I just think the evidence
does appear to be assembling and stacking

1412.43.text:
up for… that it’s likely that we may even
be in the early stages of a collapse mode

1421.78.text:
right now. It just makes sense to me to start
to prepare and I suppose that that to me means

1450.08.text:
We’re using organic gardening practices.
So we’re not using any pesticides, we’re

1456.09.text:
not using any fungicides, we’re not using
any chemical fertilisers, anything like that.

1460.05.text:
It’s mainly about trying to build soil in
whatever we can, mostly with compost and mostly

1468.21.text:
Food is more than just fuel for the body,
it’s… it’s your connection to the land.

1477.41.text:
It’s the most, food is the most intimate
connection to the land because you interact

1484.78.text:
with four of the five senses, you know the
taste and the texture and the smell and the

1494.02.text:
sight, so it’s quite an amazing thing…
to be able to enjoy good food, fresh food,

1503.83.text:
seasonal food, real food, food that doesn’t
come out of a can or a package and you mix

1510.80.text:
water with it or… I don’t understand those
types of food.

1515.03.text:
The giant middlemen in the form of huge multinational
corporations and supermarket chains, are not

1525.00.text:
able to treat farmers in a way that respects
the absolute reality and necessity of diversity.

1534.87.text:
These farmers are being pressured to grow
standard-sized apples without a single blemish,

1540.50.text:
they have to fit the machinery – that is
the harvesting machinery, the washing machinery,

1545.55.text:
the supermarket shelf and the packaging. The
end result is we burn tonnes of food every

1552.38.text:
year, the end result is that the very research
and development at university is now concerned

1559.65.text:
about transportability and the looks of products
not the nutritional value.

1566.02.text:
We don’t know now when our food naturally
grows. You know, we get watermelons in June,

1574.33.text:
in Victoria, watermelons don’t grow in June
in Victoria, you know. And I think that that’s

1581.01.text:
really disconnecting. When you wait for something
to grow in your garden, it’s a completely

1586.13.text:
different feeling because you’ve anticipated
it, you’ve cared for it, it not only tastes

1590.90.text:
delicious but you’ve got this kind of connection
with it that makes it taste even more delicious

1595.91.text:
– and the fact that you’ve waited for
it all season…

1601.44.text:
So we get some of our food from the garden,
but during the winter we haven’t had as

1609.27.text:
much coming in from the garden, so get some
vegetables from the Baw Baw Food Hub, so we’ve

1617.14.text:
been getting sacks of potatoes and sacks of
carrots and sacks of onions from them, as

1621.65.text:
well as garlic in bulk and things like butter
and cheese. They also do veggie boxes, with

1629.41.text:
a range of different vegetables from the local
area, so we’ve been getting them as we’ve

1634.93.text:
progressed through the year. Aside from that
we get our dry goods and other food from a

1643.96.text:
variety of different places. So, we’re aiming
to source our food as locally, ethically and

1650.11.text:
organically as possible, so we choose which
supplier we get different items from so that

1657.17.text:
we’re getting it from as close as possible
and grown in the best way possible for the

1663.19.text:
Because to me food consumption is a moral
act. It is also a political act. And it is

1668.94.text:
up to us, the consumer – or I like to call

1675.75.text:
– to do something about it. Because we can’t
all wait for authorities or government to

1682.15.text:
do something about it, we just have to do
things. It has to be from the bottom up.

My name’s Hayden and I build super adobe
domes, and I run workshops and I hope to do

it full time and as a real job. It’s 3.6m

a permit for it. About 95% of the building
material is earth. We’ve got a really really

large pile of earth that we’ve just pulled

is the right consistency you get to use a

on your site. So it’s really really local
materials, really really cheap, and yeah really

1851.20.text:
Yeah, this is our composting toilet setup,
which we built over the course of a few weeks

1856.37.text:
out of a combination of salvaged hardwood,
local cypress, which makes these, and, yeah,

1863.22.text:
just some other materials that we found around
the place, some hessian sacks from down the

1866.66.text:
road. It’s a pretty simple system. There’s
a urinal over on this side here, and a composting

1874.04.text:
toilet on this side. After we’ve finished
using it we put in a cup of sawdust, just

1880.40.text:
here, from the local cypress mill, and that
just helps it to… it balances the carbon

1885.31.text:
and the nitrogen and it helps it to compost
into a fertiliser.

1888.82.text:
So when we’re done with the bin, when it’s
filled up most of the way, we’ll take it

1893.75.text:
out and put it in a holding bay with all our
other bins and they’ll sit for about 300

1898.90.text:
days, and we’ll check on the compost after
that time. And during that time they’ll

1903.59.text:
just compost away until eventually they’re,
yeah, beautiful fertiliser for the garden.

1909.39.text:
We’ve used permaculture in the gardens,
where we’re trying to maximise diversity

1914.62.text:
and make sure that there’s a lot of different
kinds of plants around. We’re planting herbs

1919.19.text:
and things like that, as well, for integrated
pest management. Permaculture can be defined

1924.65.text:
in many different ways but it basically, it
stands for permanent agriculture first of

1930.08.text:
all, and then permanent culture, ok, so the
way I see it is basically it’s planning

1937.01.text:
and designing for more permanent kind of systems.
Just like nature does, really, it’s mimicking

1942.91.text:
nature. So, it’s utilising design and careful
research and planning to ensure that you’re

1948.63.text:
creating a self-cycling system that’s regenerative
and produces no waste.

1954.62.text:
So permaculture is really a design system
for both sustainable land use and sustainable

1961.66.text:
living. And so it’s addressing both the
production side of the conundrum and the consumption

1969.00.text:
side, and saying why not bring those things
back together? Well we eat food… we grow

1976.25.text:
a garden, why don’t we grow the food in
the garden and integrate that whole…? Rather

1980.58.text:
than the industrial system, which stretches
everything out in these long supply chains.

1986.46.text:
So bring it back together. And through that
a whole lot of design principals emerged,

1993.89.text:
that, you know, small-scale systems actually
made more sense than large scale ones, that

1999.41.text: you need a diversity rather than a monoculture.

2002.10.text:
And it’s not just sustainable, sustainable
is not nearly good enough…What you need

2006.52.text:
is not sustainable, you need regenerative,
and that’s exactly what permaculture provides

2010.84.text:
you the ability to do. Rather than our extractive
system, where we’ve constantly been sucking

2017.44.text:
resources out all the time, and cannibalising,
catabalising our natural capital, all the

2022.82.text:
time, rather than doing that and leaving ourselves
less and less and less ability to produce

2028.35.text:
and meet our needs in the future, if you institute
a permaculture system, you’re actually rebuilding

2036.97.text:
Sustainability’s a funny one. Yeah, I feel
like it’s a bit of a buzz word at the moment.

2045.76.text:
Sustaining. Yeah. I don’t know what it is
that you’re trying to sustain anyway, I

2051.86.text:
mean, yeah, when you think about sustainability
it means I guess that you can continue doing

2057.62.text:
what you’re doing ongoing into the future,
indefinitely. But I just don’t really think

2062.59.text:
that there’s that much that we should be
trying to sustain at the moment. We should

2066.35.text:
be looking at solutions that can improve the
land over the long term, and can improve the

2072.11.text:
lives of people. But I don’t think the rampant
inequality and the extreme concentration of

2078.51.text:
wealth in the hands of the few is something
worth sustaining. I think that’s something

2082.55.text: worth destroying and challenging and replacing.

2085.37.text:
You’re really answering what is a deep human
need, because that’s how we evolved. It’s

2092.99.text:
coming back onto a track that would allow
life to continue evolving, that would allow

2099.00.text:
for real progress. The other path is suicidal,
we are going to soon get to the point where

2107.35.text:
‘localise or die’ basically, because we
cannot continue extinguishing species, cannot

2114.58.text:
continue creating frustration, fundamentalism,
terror. We cannot continue so blatantly destroying

2125.67.text:
any form of democracy. You know, things are
going to change and I think we’ll see, you

2134.41.text:
know, that people are waking up very, very
rapidly to the benefits of localisation.

2143.17.text:
Ah, this week we're retrofitting our existing
farm shed to be a kitchen, lounge and craft

2153.37.text:
space. We want a multi-functional large area
that can be converted to different uses with

2158.85.text:
portable bits of furniture, so with the materials
we're using, we've sourced locally milled

2164.82.text:
timber from a local sawmill, and we’re also
using as many recycled materials as possible.

2170.02.text:
So we've got a bunch of floorboards and bits
of iron that we're going to use as cladding

2175.86.text:
for the internal space. We’re also going
to be doing a recycled bottle wall along the

2190.48.text:
front of the building here, to let as much
light in as possible and that’s also going

2195.72.text:
to feature some large glass doors to bring
the outside in and feature that beautiful

2200.98.text: view we've got of the property.

2204.51.text:
There's so much waste these days, of buildings
that are getting torn down or scraps of wood

2208.93.text:
that are left over from building jobs, that
we can divert those resources from landfill

2214.83.text:
and actually use them in a meaningful way
and be really creative with just making something

2308.16.text:
We’re here at the Wurruk’an kitchen/lounge
room/communal space, which we’ve been living

2314.15.text:
in now for about three or so months. I guess
the theme starts with our recycled timber.

2320.48.text:
These ones up the top and on the side here
are oak floorboards that were left over from

2326.64.text:
a building project and we were able to get
them very cheap. We’ve got some recycled

2331.49.text:
windows that there are a couple of sets around
the room. So over here you can see we’ve

2336.22.text:
used a combination of corrugated iron and
some hardwood fence palings that we were able

2340.80.text:
to get for free from demolition. We also scored
some of this splashback stuff around the sink

2346.19.text:
and the oven, which is heat proof, and that
was left over commercially and we were able

2352.59.text:
to get it for free. These beautiful bench
tops, both these ones and the larger slabs,

2359.15.text:
came from a sawmill, from Jedwood. We were
very luck to get their off-cuts and be able

2364.58.text:
to actually use them with the help of our
professional carpenter to get them to this

2369.16.text:
stage, which is really nice. Up on the roof
we’ve actually had to use some ply wood.

2373.68.text:
We were a bit short on materials to do the
whole thing with reclaimed stuff. And there’s

2378.80.text:
also insulation and framing behind all of
these walls and the ceiling now so that insulation

2386.86.text:
was also you know a bit of a compromise. We
bought that new as well cos that can be pretty

2393.16.text:
It’s been really great to have a wood-fired
stove to cook on. It feels a lot better than

2399.27.text:
cooking on an electric stove as we were before.
Just knowing that the source of energy that

2407.67.text:
we’re using to cook with is a renewable
source is better. At the moment we’ve used

2414.00.text:
some off-cuts from building, which have no
other purpose, and we’ve also sourced some

2419.19.text:
of our firewood from this property and also
from nearby forests in the way that is permitted.

2426.48.text:
So, it’s clear enough now that we need to
transition swiftly away from a fossil fuel

2432.74.text:
energy economy to an economy based on renewable
energy. Not only due to climate change, but

2438.23.text:
also because in coming years or decades fossil
energy production will inevitably peak and

2444.23.text:
decline. But we can’t just green the supply
of our energy, we also need to, I think, significantly

2453.25.text:
reduce energy demand, because there’s no
way that we can run a globalised energy-intensive

2459.28.text:
consumer society purely on renewable energy.
Yes, we need to transition to 100% renewable

2466.41.text:
energy, but that implies significantly reducing
energy demand, and it would be far easier,

2473.32.text:
obviously, to meet 100% renewable energy if
we consumed much less energy. So that should

2479.79.text:
be our goal. But given the close connection
between energy and economy, a society based

2487.44.text:
solely on renewable energy would have reduced
energy supply, and therefore would probably

2493.37.text:
have to go through a phase of economic contraction,
at least in the developed regions of the world.

2499.38.text:
So I think if we were successful in transitioning
to 100% renewable energy we wouldn’t be

2506.25.text:
able to live high-consumption, energy-intensive
lifestyles. We would need to aim for far more

2517.62.text:
The silver lining to consuming less is actually
consuming more of what we really want and

2526.90.text:
what we really long for. And that includes,
you know, hand-made, artisan products that,

2534.56.text:
you know, most people treasure much more than
some mass-produced product. It includes more

2542.67.text:
time to breathe and to sing together, to dance
together, to make things together. There’s

2551.10.text:
a whole universe of things out there that
we could do right now without money, but it

2557.76.text:
requires the insight and the courage to connect
to others, and to form groups where we can

2639.22.text:
You don’t need that much in the way of material
things if you know that your neighbours have

2644.35.text:
got your back, and anytime you get overwhelmed
by things, you can go next door and there’s

2649.14.text:
someone who’s shoulder you can cry on, or
they can come to you, or someone who’s tomatoes

2654.09.text:
you can water, then they’re coming and helping
you fix your bike, or whatever it might be.

2658.87.text:
There are just so many advantages, there are
no disadvantages to building community, and

2664.04.text:
the potential advantages are absolutely massive,
so I think that’s something we really, really

2697.92.text:
I think the benefits of living in a community
reveal themselves to you more and more each

2702.67.text:
day. There’s the strict financial benefit
of being able to share in the costs of making

2708.50.text:
this transition. And also the benefits of
being able to draw on each other’s skills

2713.52.text:
and attributes and knowledges so you don’t
have to do it alone, you don’t have to do

2717.33.text:
it financially alone, skills alone, some of
those things are very intimidating for people

2722.57.text:
trying to make that step. But more than that
it’s about being… doing it together. And

2728.57.text:
what’s possible here is possible not just
because of us as individuals but because when

2732.69.text:
we get this unique collection of individuals
together we’re capable of so much more than

2736.77.text: what we would be on our own.

2745.29.text:
So we have to do one of two things: we either
just accept that we have no community at all,

2749.28.text:
we just have a casual neighbourhood and some
nice acquaintances at work and perhaps a couple

2753.81.text:
of people that we drink with at the pub, or
we create community, intentional community.

2758.72.text:
And I think that’s the side that’s always
interested me personally as well as in my

2762.84.text:
research, is How can people create intentional…
How can you consciously do it? I know people

2768.68.text:
subconsciously do it all the time. I mean
it’s our natural position, but can you actually

2773.42.text:
do this, can you set out to create this? And
that always fascinates me. You gonna have

2777.59.text:
to come up with some idea of how you’re
gonna make decisions. Yes, we’re going to

2781.44.text:
have consensus, and yes we’re going to live
lightly on the land, and yes we’re going

2785.72.text:
to support each other and yes we’ll look
after each other’s children and elderly

2790.36.text:
and all of that sort of stuff. But it depends
whether you have any experience with doing

2795.67.text:
that. I think the other thing is that we are
losing so many of those skills from living

2803.36.text:
in community. It’s like, you know, I know
that I have to develop skills in organic gardening

2808.26.text:
if I’m going to become an organic gardener,
I know that, so therefore I also have to develop

2812.85.text:
skills in inter-human, interpersonal relationships
if I’m gonna live in community. Don’t

2816.92.text:
assume you were kind of born with that because
you weren’t. You have to learn how to cooperate,

2823.39.text:
how to put the group above the individual
and that’s very challenging.

2828.16.text:
There’s been a lot of challenges, I’m
not gonna lie. I think although we had to

2838.88.text:
live the first few months without much infrastructure,
without a warm kitchen space, without much

2844.93.text:
of a lounge room or without a whole lot of
running water and we had a composting toilet

2851.74.text:
that was sort of outside, I don’t think
the infrastructure were all that big, I think

2857.23.text:
there seemed to be a sense in solidarity in
all doing it together and that kind of gave

2861.71.text:
me a lot of comfort, knowing that we were
all kind of pulling through and stronger because

2866.41.text:
of it. So I feel like the infrastructure challenges
were a little bit problematic but they weren’t

2873.37.text:
as hard I think as the community challenges
we faced, when there was conflict in the community

2880.46.text:
and our conflict resolution around that weren’t
fully developed so yeah, I think I struggled

2887.12.text:
a lot when things were not going well and
people left and things weren’t fully resolved,

2892.44.text:
or when there was substantial difference in
the direction that people wanted to take in

2896.75.text:
the project, whether people wanted to build
lots of infrastructure or start practicing

2900.69.text:
simple, simpler living. I feel like those
chasms, those sort of divides were challenging

2907.59.text:
for me because I didn’t know where I sat
and didn’t know how to bring the group back

2911.68.text:
together again. I wanted everyone to start
working together again.

2916.55.text:
Obviously starting at a community from scratch
with people who don’t really know each other

2921.02.text:
at all and designing a property and finishing
buildings, houses and bits of infrastructure

2929.62.text:
is very challenging in the context of one-year
project, so, yeah, that social aspect of just

2937.92.text:
getting to know each other and getting decision-making
processes in place has been one of the key

2945.88.text:
challenges. Another major challenge I think
has been the group figuring out how to accommodate

2951.26.text:
a wide range of peoples’ styles of voluntary
simplicity. It can be interpreted to differing

2959.37.text:
degrees and there’s not necessarily any
right or wrong answers, so just figuring out

2964.91.text:
how the group can accommodate the variety
within our personal direction and preferences

2971.92.text:
has also been a challenging component of that
social side of things.

2996.48.text:
One of the humbling learnings I got from being
here was how difficult it is to be in community

3004.42.text:
and how in a way we have to relearn that art
– that we have broken that long tradition

3012.14.text:
of shared ritual and song and mythology and
living in one place and knowing that history.

3020.96.text:
That’s kind of been fragmented for us and
when we now come together in groups it’s

3026.96.text:
much harder to find that common culture to
draw upon in times of discord and in times

3033.14.text:
of confusion. So it’s easy for us to fragment
back into our individual desires and paths

3039.73.text:
and I know that for lots of people, as resources
become more scarce and we have to rely on

3047.52.text:
each other more, there’ll be positives to
that but there’ll also be lots of challenges.

3051.35.text:
So I’m very motivated now to keep practising
and developing those skills of communication

3057.75.text:
and conflict resolution, naming the difficulties,
bringing up the emotional challenges. And

3065.37.text:
also celebrating together, creating, relaxing,
learning how to play and dance in a group

3074.04.text:
and, it’s a real, it’s the art of being
human and the art of being together.

3081.87.text:
We’ve been living in a tent, or we were
living in a tent at the start of the year,

3090.48.text:
and yeah the tent was in a place where it
didn’t get a whole lot of sun and as it

3094.06.text:
began to rain a bit more as we were coming
into winter it didn’t dry out so it started

3098.04.text:
to get mouldy and, yeah, there was a bit of
pressure on us to do something else and we

3102.97.text:
decided that building a small house with recycled
materials would be the simplest way to do

3107.76.text: that so, yeah, so we did.

3173.81.text:
This beautiful structure behind us is the
house that we built over the course of about

3178.09.text:
three months out of pretty much entirely recycled
materials. We had to make five purchases.

3183.66.text:
We bought some cement for the foundations,
some steel bracing tape, because it was a

3188.60.text:
bit wonky, we bought some screws for the roof,
we bought some… [a tub of wood glue]…

3194.46.text:
a little tub of wood glue for, to make some
window frames…we bought chains to hold the

3198.88.text:
windows open. [hinges] Oh and we bought, there
were six things, we bought some hinges as

3202.78.text:
well. But that’s it; everything else is
recycled materials we got entirely for free.

3209.32.text:
Yeah, we went by dumpsters from demolition
sites, we looked on the website Gumtree and,

3216.58.text:
yeah, we ended up getting, yeah, pretty much
everything we needed to build a whole house

3220.78.text:
just for free. If, yeah, we can demonstrate
that it’s possible to do without three and

3226.54.text:
a half years of training and without tens
of thousands of dollars, to build a house

3232.12.text:
that is gonna be a lot better in terms of
its ecological footprint, then I think that

3237.87.text:
that can kind of disperse that knowledge more
amongst the people that might not have the

3242.34.text:
money to take part in a more conventional
sustainability movement. Yeah, so the total

3247.88.text:
cost was about $420 if you, include, yeah,
the petrol money that went into it. It’s

3252.63.text:
a lot more time consuming doing it for free,
but yeah, it’s definitely worth it. [A lot

3260.63.text:
So while I’ve been at Wurruk’an I’ve
been continuing to work for eight hours a

3264.61.text:
week for book publishing clients and that’s
enabled me to cover the small expenses that

3271.98.text:
we have at Wurruk’an. So we’ve put $30
a week into the kitty, which is, you know,

3278.55.text:
the great benefit of living in a community,
that for $30 a week each we’ve been able

3284.70.text:
to pretty much feed ourselves for the entire
year. And obviously all of us have little

3291.77.text:
extras that we like, that weren’t items
that everybody wanted, and so we’ve bought

3297.81.text:
our own, I don’t know, cheese, or bread.
I think I’m right in saying that we’ve

3303.21.text:
all spent under $100 a week this year for
our basic living costs.

3307.75.text:
[The borrower receives the full amount and
pays it back, plus interest. Either way the

3315.40.text:
interest that it collects on loans is one
of the bank’s principle sources of income.

3319.88.text:
Now Mr Moreton has obtained his loan. He has
increased his bank credit by nearly $2000.

3326.19.text:
But this credit was not transferred to him
from some other account, so where did it come

3334.00.text:
So currently the existing monetary system
essentially has a growth imperative built

3340.24.text:
into its structures, because banks create
money by loaning it into existence as interest-bearing

3345.52.text:
debt, and in order for that debt to be paid
back, plus the interest, that implies an expansion

3351.12.text:
of the monetary system. So it needs growth
for stability. But we also know that growth

3359.23.text:
is the driving force behind our environmental
problems, so if we were to transition to a

3365.79.text:
post-growth economy, as we need to do for
environmental reasons, this would require

3370.36.text:
us to create a different type of monetary
system and banking system, one that wasn’t

3375.75.text:
so dependent on growth. And I think there’s
a huge amount that governments can do to reign

3380.82.text:
in the worst aspects of the current system,
but perhaps a more promising line of opposition,

3387.98.text:
given that governments don’t seem to be
doing much, would be for individuals and households

3392.87.text:
to try to create new forms of economy. Try
to escape the existing monetary system as

3400.02.text:
far as possible. And they could do this through
things like creating local currencies, local

3405.25.text:
exchange networks and engaging in practices
like barter, and gift, and sharing. It would

3411.54.text:
be … it’s obviously so much easier for
a community to deal with the contracting economy

3417.51.text:
if communities and households shared the stuff
that they had.

3425.17.text:
So there was a long process of… what felt
like a long process of learning to communicate

3441.68.text:
with each other and it’s immensely satisfying
now to feel that that process has actually

3448.92.text:
been really successful. And to be living now
in a… with a community of people who when

3457.26.text:
problems arise know how to work through them.
And I think we’ve actually been really successful

3462.52.text:
at making those… at developing those communication
skills, and it’s a nice feeling when, you

3468.67.text:
know, when we have a meeting and someone raises
an issue and you can see the change in…

3476.06.text:
you can see the different way that people
approach it, you can see the different ways

3479.55.text:
that people sort of think about, respond to
issues, especially if, where at the beginning

3487.64.text:
of the year they might have felt a little
bit attacked now they think through the reason

3492.41.text:
for the issue coming up. Yeah I think we’re
all much better at, I think we’re probably

3498.26.text: all in some way more mature community dwellers.

3518.00.text:
Living in such close quarters with other people
as part of a community, especially on quite

3525.21.text:
a small scale where we all use the same lounge
room and kitchen and there’s you know seven

3529.36.text:
or eight of us in that same space on a daily
basis, it certainly presents a lot of challenges

3535.41.text:
on a personal and a group level, that are
just inherent to human beings and you know

3543.06.text:
families and communities and all types of
human relationships. So it’s certainly been

3547.40.text:
challenging but I know for myself that’s
made me look inward and examine my own personal

3557.03.text:
journey and where I’m at and how my own
psychology is evolving and just you know,

3564.83.text:
if you feel a bit down one day or feel a bit
anxious about how someone else is acting,

3571.13.text:
it’s ended up kind of flipping around and
making me examine how I’m contributing to

3577.79.text:
those sorts of dynamics or social situations
and just, yeah, trying to learn more about

3603.04.text:
So I’m gonna be building my house in less
than a week now. I’ve got fourteen people

3608.01.text:
coming out to learn how to build a tiny house
on wheels, and I’ve been gathering materials

3614.22.text:
for the last couple of months in Melbourne
and around the local area to build a tiny

3619.87.text:
house on wheels out of recycled materials.
You know, we’ve got a few rough plans but

3624.11.text:
being a tiny house it’s quite easy to go
with the flow and being recycled materials

3629.97.text:
we’ve had to adapt to that and it’s gonna
be a bit of a jigsaw puzzle, I guess.

3677.28.text:
So there’s a major, major benefit if you
don’t get trapped into working 20, 30, 40

3683.75.text:
years to pay the mortgage on your two big
McMansions, boy oh boy have you gained a lot

3690.61.text:
of time and freedom from worry to do other
things. And in a sane world we would be able

3697.61.text:
to build a very nice little house for, I reckon,
$10,000 at most, and you can do it for less

3703.09.text:
than that if you like, and that’s a perfectly
adequate house. Now, you’ve saved $400,000

3707.48.text:
there, by the time you take in the payment
of interest and the loans to the bank and

3715.58.text:
tax on the money. That’s not negligible;
there is a benefit for moving to simpler ways.

3725.44.text:
So we’re three days into the workshop and
it’s going really well. As you can see we’ve

3731.05.text:
got the full timber frame of the walls up
and the group’s working really well together.

3736.10.text:
They’re all learning off each other and
Nick, our carpenter, is doing a really great

3740.50.text:
job, so I feel very lucky to have everyone
working so hard and we’re on schedule.

3750.48.text:
I was really humbled by the good will, the
energy, and all of the contributions brought

3755.90.text:
by everyone who made it possible. It was just
an amazing week of everyone’s energy vibing

3762.30.text:
and making this beautiful house possible,
and, you know, I’ve got a little bit left

3766.93.text:
to do but I’ve basically had people come
and build me a house with really great intentions

3771.86.text:
and we all learnt a whole lot. And it couldn’t
have gone any better. I’d say it was probably

3778.18.text: the best week of my life without a doubt.

3792.16.text:
There’s a whole history of these sort of
energy descent ideas and permaculture being

3800.00.text:
associated with a move to the country, a move
to rural areas as a place that’s a better

3806.74.text:
place to be more self-reliant. And that still
may be true, but for most people there’s

3817.33.text:
both a necessity and an advantage in looking
at where they live already. And for most Australians

3826.69.text:
that is some sort of detached housing in what
we call suburbia, whether that’s in our

3833.70.text:
capital cities or whether it’s in similar
housing in our regional towns and even villages

3840.58.text:
like the one we live in – that most people
are living in those separate houses on small

3846.72.text:
blocks. And what that template of living makes
possible is it’s possible to incrementally

3855.77.text:
adjust what is happening there and provide
a lot of people’s needs by growing food,

3862.45.text:
by modifying the house to make it more…
ah, less dependent on energy, by harvesting

3869.28.text:
some of the water, and by using some of the
space that exists in our relatively large

3875.08.text:
houses to start doing more in the household
economy. Doing things for ourselves, rather

3884.97.text:
One of the things that’s most exciting about
the intentional communities movement now is

3888.71.text:
that it’s like we have right across the
landscape hundreds of experiments about how

3893.63.text:
to live in a way that confronts and resolves
issues associated with climate change and

3899.07.text:
peak oil, you know, environmental damage on
a global scale. Instead of just having a one-way

3907.88.text:
solution, which just says this is the way
that we have to go forward to resolve this,

3912.09.text:
instead we’ve got all of these little bubbles
of creative responses and you know new ways

3919.17.text:
of living and being together and, building
lives together. Patterns of settlement and

3924.14.text:
patterns of production are popping up all
across the landscape, each offering different

3928.95.text:
pathways, and it’s almost like the… as
more of these emerge we have more opportunities

3937.51.text:
Ideally I’d like to see more initiatives
like this, where people with resources and

3943.87.text:
land and spaces, making them available to
allow, you know, passionate and enthusiastic

3951.32.text:
people to live more self-sufficiently and
demonstrate through example that there are

3971.98.text:
So there’s so much that we can do right
now, without spending any money, to greatly

3977.09.text:
enrich our lives. And let’s not be fooled
by this idea that we have so much choice in

3985.78.text:
the modern economy and that our lives would
be so limited if we were to choose a different

3992.41.text:
path. We have not even begun to explore the
potential for more diversified, localised

4002.71.text:
There are reasons for pessimism, because it’s
a big, big task, and we’re in a lot of bother,

4010.10.text:
and we are not very far down the path to the
kind of consciousness that we need. But there

4016.59.text:
are a lot of strong reasons for optimism.
One is, that the vision of an alternative

4027.15.text:
way is, I think, so attractive, it’s what
keeps me going, and it’s so easily done.

4037.19.text:
We could do it in weeks, if we wanted to.
It’s about moving to ways that would liberate

4045.30.text:
You don’t want to wait until you have absolutely
no choice. So I would say it’s a bit like

4051.41.text:
we’re standing on the edge of a cliff and
we’re going over the edge, like it or not

4054.91.text:
we’re going over the edge. That’s not
up for debate. So what are you going to do?

4059.93.text:
Are you going to stand on the edge of that
cliff and wait for someone to shove you off?

4063.95.text:
Or are you going to put on your parachute
and jump? Because, not that base-jumping is

4068.45.text:
without its risks, but it’s a lot less risky
than going over the edge without a parachute!

4074.41.text:
So let’s not think of it as good guys and
bad guys, and let’s not believe for a minute

4079.09.text:
that the way we’ll change it is by getting
some good guys to go into those large structures.

4084.62.text:
Let’s look systemically at how we can shift
towards smaller structures with more holistic

4092.13.text:
knowledge, underpinnings, and that really
is the localizing path.

4098.90.text:
When you know how to live simply, the sense
of freedom can be just overwhelming. There’s

4103.72.text:
nothing as addictive as freedom, and there’s
nothing as attractive either. So, I think

4110.33.text:
if we find the right way to explain our ideas
to people, and explain the ideas that are

4116.89.text:
fundamentally workable in the first place,
then there is so much that can be achieved,

4123.75.text:
I came to Wurruk’an wanting to explore a
really radical form of voluntary simplicity,

4130.96.text:
because I felt a real sense of urgency around
the various crises that the world is facing

4136.18.text:
at the moment and radical simplicity seems
to me to be the best and most logical response.

4144.91.text:
After the experience this year of living in
community, and despite all of the challenges,

4149.70.text:
I feel really strongly that this is the right
way for me to live. So, yeah, my intention

4158.35.text:
is to return to New Zealand and find or found
a community and in the long term I’m really

4168.06.text:
hoping to live in a community that operates
in a gift economy. That feels like a right

4173.64.text:
and responsible way to live, or thing to work
towards.

4180.82.text:
The person I was at the start of the year
is vastly different to the person I am at

4185.69.text:
the end of the year. As I would hope would
be the case for every other year for the rest

4189.69.text:
of my life. My plans for the future extend
as far as I should probably pick that zucchini

4193.28.text:
over there. Beyond that, not many plans. But
I… I’m imagining that Rachel and I will

4200.92.text:
probably stick around here at Wurruk’an
for a little while. I’m feeling pretty settled

4206.50.text:
here, it’s feeling a lot like home. I think
the number one thing that’s been solidified

4211.05.text:
in my mind this year is that my favourite
things in the world are imagination, creativity,

4218.02.text:
and teamwork. And the combination of those
three things is, yeah, personally the recipe

4225.42.text: for living in a beautiful way in the future.

4235.69.text:
I love community, I love other people, I love
living and spending time with other people.

4244.57.text:
I don’t know whether or not living in an
intentional community is part of my future.

4250.76.text:
One thing that I knew coming here was that…
living in community is a challenge, it involves

4265.60.text: effort, and that that effort is worth it.

4270.07.text:
Yeah, it’s been a really transformational
year for me… I didn’t expect to have the

4275.63.text:
opportunity to be constructing my own house
this year, so it’s been very humbling to

4280.57.text:
have the generosity of all the people involved
and the land owner to allow me to do that,

4285.74.text:
because it’s been quite a journey to collect
the materials and go through the process of

4290.41.text:
building over an extended period of time,
so that’s just been fantastic and blown

4295.69.text:
my expectations out of the water. So, once
I’ve finished my house, which will be sometime

4300.80.text:
early in 2016, I plan to relocate it to Melbourne,
hopefully in a back yard somewhere that affords

4307.68.text:
me a location where I can ride my bike and
catch public transport without having to be

4311.94.text:
car reliant. But after moving it to Melbourne
and living there for a little while and enjoying

4317.80.text:
a bit of city life, I don’t really have
a plan. I’m very happy to have that feeling

4323.27.text:
of freedom and liberation for the first time
in my life and I’m going to make the most

4330.09.text:
One thing I get paralysed by is this sense
of having to do it right, somehow not making

4335.62.text:
mistakes. And we’ve made so many mistakes
living here, you know, there are buildings

4341.22.text:
that are leaky, there are disagreements that
never got resolved, there are contradictions

4347.76.text:
in the way we’re living, and compromises
that we had to make. So, from one perspective,

4353.69.text:
we failed, we haven’t transformed the world
or led this perfect example. And from another

4360.88.text:
perspective, those very failings are our gifts,
and they are the offering, and they are the

4366.03.text:
learnings, because we’ve risked and we’ve
been willing to put our values on the line,

4372.46.text:
and we’ve been willing to test these ideas
and try and bring them into, you know, the

4377.63.text:
shared reality. You know, no one holds the
answers, no one has the perfect solution,

4385.23.text:
it’s gonna require a response from everyone
if we’re going to be moving towards a more

4391.43.text:
wholesome and enduring way of life. And, you
know, the challenges, the failings, the mistakes,

4398.49.text:
the triumphs, they’re all part of the story
of change and I just hope that other people

4407.78.text:
can feel that encouragement to make their
own beautiful mistakes along the way to…
